‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
It is not a common topic in data science interviews, but understanding the Sobolev inequality can be helpful in some cases involving partial differential equations and optimization.
Tags: Sobolev inequality, functional analysis, partial differential equations, Lebesgue spaces, optimization
Sobolev inequality: $\|u\|_{L^{p^*}(\Omega)} \le C \|\nabla u\|_{L^p(\Omega)}$,
In the Cram√©r-Rao inequality, $\hat{\theta}$ is an unbiased estimator of the parameter $\theta$, and $I(\theta)$ is the Fisher information of the parameter. This inequality provides a lower bound on the variance of an unbiased estimator, which is useful in statistics and estimation theory. Click to expand

üìä Quants

The Cram√©r-Rao inequality is important in quantitative finance for parameter estimation, model fitting, and risk management, as it provides a lower bound on the accuracy of estimators.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

The Cram√©r-Rao inequality is crucial in AI research, particularly in areas like machine learning, statistical modeling, and parameter estimation, where understanding the accuracy of estimators is essential.

üìà Data Scientists

Understanding the Cram√©r-Rao inequality is useful for data science interviews, as it is a fundamental result in statistics and estimation theory, with applications in model fitting and parameter estimation.
Tags: Cram√©r-Rao inequality, statistics, estimation theory, Fisher information, parameter estimation
Cram√©r-Rao inequality: $\text{Var}(\hat{\theta}) \ge \frac{1}{I(\theta)}$,
In the Paley-Zygmund inequality, X is a random variable, and $\alpha$ is a positive constant. This inequality provides a lower bound on the probability that the absolute difference between X and its expected value is at least $\alpha$ times the expected absolute difference. It is useful in probability theory and has applications in various fields, such as signal processing and information theory. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Paley-Zygmund inequality can be useful in quantitative finance for bounding probabilities and analyzing tail risks in financial models.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Paley-Zygmund inequality is relevant in AI research, particularly in areas like probability theory, signal processing, and information theory, where understanding tail probabilities is important.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
It is not a common topic in data science interviews, but understanding the Paley-Zygmund inequality can be helpful in some cases involving probability theory and tail risk analysis.
Tags: Paley-Zygmund inequality, probability theory, tail risk, signal processing, information theory
Paley-Zygmund inequality: $\Pr(|X - E[X]| \ge \alpha E[|X - E[X]|]) \ge (1-\alpha)^2 \frac{E[(X - E[X])^2]}{E[|X - E[X]|]^2}$,
In the Rademacher-Menchov inequality, $\varepsilon_i$ are independent Rademacher random variables (taking values +1 or -1 with equal probability), and $a_i$ are real numbers. This inequality provides an upper bound on the variance of a sum of Rademacher random variables, which is useful in probability theory and has applications in various fields, such as concentration inequalities and learning theory. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Rademacher-Menchov inequality can be useful in quantitative finance for bounding variances and analyzing tail risks in financial models.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Rademacher-Menchov inequality is relevant in AI research, particularly in areas like probability theory, concentration inequalities, and learning theory, where understanding the behavior of random variables is important.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
It is not a common topic in data science interviews, but understanding the Rademacher-Menchov inequality can be helpful in some cases involving probability theory and tail risk analysis.
Tags: Rademacher-Menchov inequality, probability theory, concentration inequalities, learning theory, tail risk
Rademacher-Menchov inequality: $\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^n \varepsilon_i a_i) \le \frac{1}{4} \sum_{i=1}^n a_i^2$,
In the Rayleigh quotient, the expression represents the range of eigenvalues of a symmetric matrix A, where Œª_min and Œª_max are the minimum and maximum eigenvalues, respectively. This relationship is useful for understanding the properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors in linear algebra and optimization problems. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Rayleigh quotient is important in quantitative finance research for optimization problems, such as portfolio optimization and risk management.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Rayleigh quotient has limited direct application in AI research, but it may be useful in understanding linear algebra concepts.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Rayleigh quotient might be asked in a data science interview to test the candidate's understanding of linear algebra and optimization techniques.
Tags: Rayleigh quotient, eigenvalues, linear algebra, optimization, symmetric matrix
Rayleigh quotient: $\lambda_{\min}(A) \le \frac{x^TAx}{x^Tx} \le \lambda_{\max}(A)$
Courant-Fisher theorem states the k-th eigenvalue of a symmetric matrix A can be found by minimizing the Rayleigh quotient over all k-dimensional subspaces U_k. This theorem is useful for finding eigenvalues and solving optimization problems in various fields, including finance and engineering. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Courant-Fisher theorem is important in quantitative finance research for solving optimization problems, such as portfolio optimization and risk management.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Courant-Fisher theorem has limited direct application in AI research, but it may be useful in understanding linear algebra concepts.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
The Courant-Fisher theorem might be asked in a data science interview to test the candidate's understanding of linear algebra and optimization techniques.
Tags: Courant-Fisher theorem, eigenvalues, linear algebra, optimization, symmetric matrix
Courant-Fisher: $\lambda_k(A) = \min_{U_k} \max_{x \in U_k} \frac{x^TAx}{x^Tx}$
Gershgorin's theorem states that the eigenvalues of a matrix A lie within the union of disks centered at the diagonal elements a_ii with radii R_i, which is the sum of the absolute values of the off-diagonal elements in the i-th row. This theorem is useful for estimating the location of eigenvalues and understanding the properties of matrices. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Gershgorin's theorem is useful in quantitative finance research for understanding the properties of matrices and estimating eigenvalues, which can be applied in portfolio optimization and risk management.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Gershgorin's theorem might be asked in a data science interview to test the candidate's understanding of linear algebra and matrix properties.
Tags: Gershgorin's theorem, eigenvalues, linear algebra, matrix properties, estimation
Gershgorin's theorem: $\lambda(A) \in \bigcup_{i=1}^n B(a_{ii}, R_i)$
Hadwiger's inequality provides an upper bound on the volume of a convex body K in n-dimensional space, given the radii r_i of its n inradii. This inequality is useful for understanding the geometric properties of convex bodies and has applications in computational geometry and optimization. Click to expand

Hadwiger's inequality might be asked in a data science interview to test the candidate's understanding of geometric properties of convex bodies and optimization techniques.
Tags: Hadwiger's inequality, convex bodies, volume, inradii, optimization
Hadwiger's inequality: $V(K) \le \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \left(\frac{2}{e}\right)^{\frac{n-1}{2}} \prod_{i=1}^n r_i$
Bonferroni's inequality provides an upper bound on the probability of the union of events A_i, taking into account the pairwise intersections of the events. This inequality is useful for understanding the properties of probabilities and has applications in statistics and probability theory. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

üìà Data Scientists

Tags: Bonferroni's inequality, probability, union of events, statistics, risk management
Bonferroni's inequality: $\Pr\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i\right) \le \sum_{i=1}^n \Pr(A_i) - \sum_{1 \le i < j \le n} \Pr(A_i \cap A_j)$
Boole's inequality provides an upper bound on the probability of the union of events A_i, without considering the intersections of the events. This inequality is useful for understanding the properties of probabilities and has applications in statistics and probability theory. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Tags: Boole's inequality, probability, union of events, statistics, risk management
Boole's inequality: $\Pr\left(\bigcup_{i=1}^n A_i\right) \le \sum_{i=1}^n \Pr(A_i)$
Nash inequality relates the L^2 norm, L^1 norm, and the gradient of a function u in a domain Œ©, providing a bound on the L^2 norm in terms of the gradient and L^1 norm. This inequality is useful for understanding the properties of functions and has applications in partial differential equations and mathematical analysis. Click to expand

Tags: Nash inequality, L^2 norm, L^1 norm, gradient, partial differential equations
Nash inequality: $\|u\|_{L^2(\Omega)}^2 \le C \|\nabla u\|_{L^2(\Omega)} \|u\|_{L^1(\Omega)}^{\frac{n-2}{n}}$
Hardy-Littlewood-Sobolev inequality provides a bound on the L^q norm of a function u in a domain Œ© in terms of its gradient's L^p norm. This inequality is useful for understanding the properties of functions and has applications in partial differential equations and mathematical analysis. Click to expand

Hardy-Littlewood-Sobolev: $\|u\|_{L^q(\Omega)} \le C \|\nabla u\|_{L^p(\Omega)}$

Approximation Algorithms

Greedy set cover uses an approximation algorithm with a logarithmic factor of the input size, n, as an upper bound on its solution quality. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Primarily applicable to portfolio optimization or combinatorial finance problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Applicable in AI planning, constraint satisfaction, and feature selection.

üìà Data Scientists

Used in algorithm design and optimization problems in data science.
Tags: Greedy algorithm, set cover, approximation
Greedy set cover: $\text{Approx}(\text{SC}) = O(\log n)$,
Metric TSP algorithm provides a 1.5 approximation factor of the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Useful for efficient routing in trading systems and network design in finance.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Relevant in AI for pathfinding, robotic navigation, and clustering.

üìà Data Scientists

Commonly encountered in data science for clustering and optimization problems.
Tags: Traveling Salesman Problem, approximation, metric
Metric TSP: $\text{Approx}(\text{TSP}) \le 1.5 \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Minimum vertex cover approximation algorithm provides a solution no more than twice the optimal value. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Less relevant in quantitative finance, but can be applied in some graph-based financial networks.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Useful for AI research in social networks analysis and graph-based problems.

üìà Data Scientists

Can be asked in interviews for algorithmic problem-solving and graph theory.
Tags: Vertex cover, approximation, graph theory
Minimum vertex cover: $\text{Approx}(\text{MVC}) \le 2 \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Max-cut approximation algorithm guarantees a solution at least half of the optimal value. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Relevant in portfolio optimization and financial networks partitioning.

Tags: Max-cut, graph partitioning, approximation
Max-cut: $\text{Approx}(\text{MC}) \ge \frac{1}{2} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Max-k-cut algorithm guarantees an approximation factor of k/(k-1) of the optimal solution. Click to expand

Tags: Max k-cut, graph clustering, approximation
Max-k-cut: $\text{Approx}(\text{Max k-cut}) \ge \frac{k}{k-1} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Knapsack approximation algorithm guarantees a solution within (1 - Œµ) of the optimal value. Click to expand

Can be asked in data science interviews for optimization and location problems.
Tags: Facility location, approximation, clustering
Facility location: $\text{Approx}(\text{FL}) \le 2 \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Local search provides an approximation algorithm with a solution at least as good as the optimal value. Click to expand

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for optimization, such as in trading strategies and risk management.

Greedy matching algorithm guarantees a solution at least half the optimal value. Click to expand

Fermat primality test gives an upper bound on the probability of false positives. Click to expand

Coupon collector: $\text{E}[T] = n \cdot \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{i}$,
PageRank algorithm calculates the probability of a user visiting a page as a linear combination of the expected number of inbound links and the uniform distribution. Click to expand

Tags: PageRank, network analysis, ranking
PageRank: $\text{Prob}(\text{rank}) = \alpha \cdot \text{E}[X] + (1-\alpha) \cdot \frac{1}{n}$,

Graph Algorithms

Multiway cut problem aims to find a cut with minimum cost in a graph, and the approximation algorithm guarantees a solution with cost at most twice the optimal solution. This problem appears in clustering, network design, and image segmentation. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for graph-based optimization problems, but not a central concept.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
A topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, approximation, and combinatorial optimization.
Tags: Multiway cut, graph algorithms, approximation
Multiway cut: $\text{Approx}(\text{MWC}) \le 2 \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Johnson's algorithm is an approximation algorithm for the scheduling problem, where the goal is to minimize the maximum completion time. The algorithm guarantees a schedule with maximum completion time at most 2 - 1/k times the optimal. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for scheduling and resource allocation, but not a central concept.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in AI for scheduling and resource allocation in parallel and distributed computing.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for scheduling, approximation algorithms, and resource allocation.
Tags: Johnson's algorithm, scheduling, approximation
Johnson's algorithm: $\text{Approx}(\text{SM}) \le 2 - \frac{1}{k} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Minimum spanning tree (MST) algorithms aim to find an optimal tree connecting all vertices in a graph with minimum cost. MST is a fundamental problem in graph theory, with applications in network design, clustering, and transportation. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network design and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Crucial in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A common topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Minimum spanning tree, graph algorithms, optimization
Minimum spanning tree: $\text{Approx}(\text{MST}) = \text{OPT}$,
Prim's algorithm is a greedy algorithm for finding the minimum spanning tree of a graph, guaranteeing an optimal solution. It is widely used in network design, clustering, and transportation optimization problems. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network design and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Crucial in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A common topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Prim's algorithm, graph algorithms, optimization
Prim's algorithm: $\text{Approx}(\text{MST-Prim}) = \text{OPT}$,
Kruskal's algorithm is a greedy algorithm for finding the minimum spanning tree of a graph, guaranteeing an optimal solution. It is widely used in network design, clustering, and transportation optimization problems. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network design and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Crucial in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A common topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Kruskal's algorithm, graph algorithms, optimization
Kruskal's algorithm: $\text{Approx}(\text{MST-Kruskal}) = \text{OPT}$,
Boruvka's algorithm, also known as Sollin's algorithm, is an algorithm for finding the minimum spanning tree of a graph, guaranteeing an optimal solution. It is widely used in network design, clustering, and transportation optimization problems. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network design and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Boruvka's algorithm, Sollin's algorithm, optimization
Boruvka's algorithm: $\text{Approx}(\text{MST-Boruvka}) = \text{OPT}$,
Max flow-min cut theorem states that the maximum flow in a network is equal to the capacity of the minimum cut. This theorem is fundamental in network flow problems and combinatorial optimization. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for portfolio optimization, risk management, and resource allocation.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for graph-based problems, optimization, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Max flow-min cut, network flow, optimization
Max flow-min cut: $\text{MaxFlow}(G) = \text{MinCut}(G)$,
Edmonds-Karp algorithm is an implementation of the Ford-Fulkerson method for computing the maximum flow in a flow network, guaranteeing an optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network design and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Edmonds-Karp, max flow, optimization
Edmonds-Karp algorithm: $\text{MaxFlow}(\text{EK}) = \text{OPT}$,
Ford-Fulkerson algorithm is a greedy algorithm for computing the maximum flow in a flow network, guaranteeing an optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network design and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and network analysis.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for graph algorithms, optimization, and network design.
Tags: Ford-Fulkerson, max flow, optimization
Ford-Fulkerson algorithm: $\text{MaxFlow}(\text{FF}) = \text{OPT}$,
Spectral clustering is a technique for partitioning data into clusters, where the approximation is bounded by the square root of twice the optimal solution. This method is particularly useful for graph partitioning and image segmentation. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for clustering and risk management applications.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for graph-based problems, clustering, and image segmentation.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for clustering, graph algorithms, and image processing.
Tags: Spectral clustering, graph partitioning, image segmentation
Spectral clustering: $\text{Approx}(\text{SC}) \le \sqrt{2 \cdot \text{OPT}}$,
Traveling salesman LP is a linear programming relaxation of the TSP problem, where the approximation is bounded by twice the optimal solution. This method provides a lower bound for the TSP problem and is used for solving TSP heuristics. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for routing and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for combinatorial optimization and routing problems.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for combinatorial optimization, linear programming, and heuristics.
Tags: Traveling salesman LP, TSP, linear programming
Traveling salesman LP: $\text{Approx}(\text{TSP-LP}) \le 2 \cdot \text{OPT}$,

Numerical Algorithms

SVD image compression is a technique that leverages Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) to approximate an image matrix, keeping only the most significant singular values. This results in a compressed image with minimal information loss. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for dimensionality reduction and data compression purposes.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for image processing, dimensionality reduction, and data compression.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for image processing, linear algebra, and dimensionality reduction techniques.
Tags: SVD, image compression, dimensionality reduction
SVD image compression: $\text{Approx}(\text{SVD}) \ge \text{OPT}$,
AKS primality is an algorithm for determining if a given number is a prime. The algorithm is deterministic, polynomial-time, and guarantees that the probability of a number being prime is 1 when the algorithm concludes it is prime. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Not directly applicable to quantitative finance but can be used in cryptography.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important in AI for cryptography, number theory, and security applications.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê
Less likely to be asked in data science interviews, but may appear in discussions on cryptography and number theory.
Tags: AKS primality, prime numbers, cryptography
AKS primality: $\text{Prob}(\text{prime}) = 1$,
Load balancing is the problem of distributing tasks or resources among servers or processors to minimize the maximum load. The approximation factor for many load balancing algorithms is at most twice the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for optimizing computing resources and task distribution.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for parallel and distributed computing, resource allocation, and optimization.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for resource allocation, optimization, and parallel computing.
Tags: Load balancing, resource allocation, optimization
Load balancing: $\text{Approx}(\text{LB}) \le 2 \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Linear programming rounding is a technique used to find an integer solution to a linear programming problem by rounding the optimal fractional solution. The approximation factor of this technique is equal to or greater than the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for optimization and integer programming problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for optimization, integer programming, and combinatorial problems.

Tags: Linear programming rounding, integer programming, optimization
Linear programming rounding: $\text{Approx}(\text{LP}) \ge \text{OPT}$,

Data Structures

Bloom filters are probabilistic data structures used to test whether an element is a member of a set. They have a false positive probability determined by the number of hash functions (k), the number of items (n), and the size of the bit array (m). Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for fast membership queries in large datasets with limited false positives.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for efficient data storage, querying, and approximate membership testing.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for efficient data structures, hashing, and error-tolerant algorithms.
Tags: Bloom filter, false positive, probabilistic data structure
Bloom filter: $\text{Prob}(\text{FP}) \le (1 - e^{-kn/m})^k$,
Randomized treaps are a type of binary search tree with randomized priorities assigned to each node. The expected height of a randomized treap with n elements is O(log n), providing good balance and efficient search, insert, and delete operations. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for efficient search and retrieval of financial data.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in AI for efficient data structures and search algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding balanced data structures and randomized algorithms.
Tags: Randomized treaps, binary search tree, data structure
Randomized treaps: $\text{E}[\text{Height}] = O(\log n)$,

Online Algorithms

The ski-rental problem is an online algorithm problem in which an individual must decide whether to rent or buy skis. The competitive ratio for this problem is at most 2, meaning the online algorithm's cost is at most twice the offline optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Not directly applicable to quantitative finance but can be used for online decision making and cost optimization.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for online decision making, competitive analysis, and optimization.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding online algorithms and competitive analysis.
Tags: Ski-rental problem, online algorithms, competitive ratio
Ski-rental problem: $\text{CompetitiveRatio}(\text{SR}) \le 2$,
Online paging is an online algorithm problem in which a limited number of pages must be stored in cache memory while minimizing page faults. The competitive ratio for this problem is at most k+1, where k is the cache size. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for cache management and minimizing latency in financial data retrieval.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for cache management, memory allocation, and online algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding cache management, online algorithms, and memory allocation.
Tags: Online paging, cache management, competitive ratio
Online paging: $\text{CompetitiveRatio}(\text{Paging}) \le k+1$,
The multiplicative weight update algorithm is an iterative optimization method that maintains weights for a set of variables. The approximation factor of this algorithm is at least 1/Œµ times the optimal solution, where Œµ is the desired precision. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for portfolio optimization, risk management, and online learning.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for online learning, optimization, and multi-armed bandit problems.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding online learning, optimization, and iterative algorithms.
Tags: Multiplicative weight update, optimization, online learning
Multiplicative weight update: $\text{Approx}(\text{MWU}) \ge \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \cdot \text{OPT}$,

Other

The set cover linear programming relaxation is an approximation algorithm for the set cover problem, a classical NP-hard problem. The approximation factor for this algorithm is O(log n), where n is the number of elements in the set. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for portfolio optimization and combinatorial optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for combinatorial optimization, resource allocation, and approximation algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding linear programming, approximation algorithms, and NP-hard problems.
Tags: Set cover, linear programming, approximation factor
Set cover LP: $\text{Approx}(\text{SC-LP}) = O(\log n)$,
Max-SAT is an optimization problem that seeks to maximize the number of satisfied clauses in a Boolean formula. The approximation algorithm guarantees at least 1/2 times the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for constraint satisfaction and optimization problems in finance models.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for constraint satisfaction, optimization, and logic-based reasoning.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding constraint satisfaction, optimization, and approximation algorithms.
Tags: Max-SAT, approximation algorithm, constraint satisfaction
Max-SAT: $\text{Approx}(\text{Max-SAT}) \ge \frac{1}{2} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Max k-CNF-SAT is a generalization of Max-SAT, where each clause has exactly k literals. The approximation algorithm guarantees at least (k-1)/k times the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for constraint satisfaction and optimization problems with k-literal clauses.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for constraint satisfaction, optimization, and logic-based reasoning with k-literal clauses.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
A topic in data science interviews for understanding constraint satisfaction, optimization, and k-literal clauses.
Tags: Max k-CNF-SAT, approximation algorithm, constraint satisfaction
Max k-CNF-SAT: $\text{Approx}(\text{Max k-CNF-SAT}) \ge \frac{k-1}{k} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Vertex cover linear programming relaxation is an approximation algorithm for the vertex cover problem, another classical NP-hard problem. The approximation factor for this algorithm is 2, meaning that the solution is at most twice the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for network-based optimization and risk management.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for graph-based optimization, resource allocation, and approximation algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding linear programming, graph theory, and NP-hard problems.
Tags: Vertex cover, linear programming, approximation factor
Vertex cover LP: $\text{Approx}(\text{VC-LP}) \le 2 \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Dilworth's theorem states that in a partially ordered set, the size of the largest antichain equals the minimum number of chains needed to cover the entire set. This theorem is used to analyze the structure of partially ordered sets and their partitions. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for analyzing order relationships in multi-objective optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in AI for constraint satisfaction and ordering problems in partially ordered sets.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
A topic in data science interviews for understanding partial orders, antichains, and chains in combinatorial problems.
Tags: Dilworth's theorem, partially ordered set, antichain
Dilworth's theorem: $\text{ChainPartition}(P) = \text{Width}(P)$,
Graham's algorithm is an approximation algorithm for the makespan minimization problem on parallel identical machines. The algorithm guarantees a makespan at most 4/3 times the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for scheduling tasks, load balancing, and resource allocation on parallel machines.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for parallel processing, load balancing, and efficient resource allocation.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding approximation algorithms, scheduling, and load balancing.
Tags: Graham's algorithm, makespan, load balancing
Graham's algorithm: $\text{Approx}(\text{Makespan}) \le \frac{4}{3} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
List scheduling is an approximation algorithm for the makespan minimization problem on m parallel identical machines. The algorithm guarantees a makespan at most 2 - 1/m times the optimal solution. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for efficient scheduling of tasks, optimizing computational resources, and reducing latency.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for parallel processing, resource allocation, and efficient scheduling of tasks.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding approximation algorithms, scheduling, and parallel processing.
Tags: List scheduling, makespan, parallel processing
List scheduling: $\text{Approx}(\text{LS}) \le 2 - \frac{1}{m} \cdot \text{OPT}$,
Dinic's algorithm is an efficient algorithm for computing the maximum flow in a flow network. It guarantees the correct maximum flow value in the given network. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for modeling flow networks, optimizing transport, and minimizing risk in financial systems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for network flow problems, optimization, and graph algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding graph algorithms, network flows, and optimization.
Tags: Dinic's algorithm, maximum flow, flow network
Dinic's algorithm: $\text{MaxFlow}(\text{Dinic}) = \text{OPT}$,
The push-relabel algorithm is another efficient algorithm for computing the maximum flow in a flow network. It also guarantees the correct maximum flow value in the given network. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for modeling flow networks, optimizing transport, and risk management in financial systems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for network flow problems, optimization, and graph algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding graph algorithms, network flows, and optimization techniques.
Tags: Push-relabel algorithm, maximum flow, flow network
Push-relabel algorithm: $\text{MaxFlow}(\text{PR}) = \text{OPT}$,
Randomized incremental construction is a general technique for constructing geometric and combinatorial objects. It uses randomization to simplify the analysis of the algorithm's complexity, which is typically O(n log n) for most problems. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for constructing complex geometric and combinatorial structures for risk management and optimization problems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for geometric and combinatorial algorithms, randomized algorithms, and computational geometry.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding randomized algorithms, geometric and combinatorial constructions.
Tags: Randomized incremental construction, complexity, randomization
Randomized incremental construction: $\text{E}[\text{Complexity}] = O(n \log n)$,
Yao's minimax principle is a method for proving lower bounds on the performance of algorithms, especially in the context of online algorithms and decision-making under uncertainty. It relates the worst-case performance of a randomized algorithm to the best-case performance of a deterministic algorithm. Click to expand

üìä Quants

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
Used in quantitative finance for analyzing the performance of algorithms and decision-making strategies in uncertain environments.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for proving lower bounds on algorithm performance and designing optimal algorithms under uncertainty.

üìà Data Scientists

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
A topic in data science interviews for understanding algorithm analysis, lower bounds, and decision-making under uncertainty.
Tags: Yao's minimax principle, lower bound, algorithm performance
Yao's minimax principle: $\text{LowerBound}(\text{R}) \ge \text{UpperBound}(\text{D})$,
A Nash equilibrium is a solution concept in game theory where each player's strategy is optimal given the strategies of all other players. In a Nash equilibrium, the payoff of each player is at least as good as the optimal payoff. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used in quantitative finance for modeling strategic interactions among agents and predicting market behavior.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI for multi-agent systems, reinforcement learning, and modeling strategic interactions.

üìà Data Scientists

A topic in data science interviews for understanding game theory, equilibrium concepts, and strategic decision-making.
Tags: Nash equilibrium, game theory, payoff
Nash equilibrium: $\text{Payoff}(\text{NE}) \ge \text{OPT}$,
Centrality Measures in Network Science
Centrality Measures Click to expand
Centrality Measures in Network Science
Degree centrality measures the number of edges connected to a node, normalized by the maximum possible degree (n-1). It is useful for identifying influential nodes in a network. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Degree centrality can be used to analyze the importance of nodes in financial networks, such as banks or assets, and their potential impact on market stability.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It can help identify central nodes in knowledge graphs or social networks used for AI research.

üìà Data Scientists

It may come up during discussions about graph-based algorithms and identifying important nodes in a network.
Tags: degree centrality, network analysis, graph theory
Degree centrality: $C_D(v) = \frac{\deg(v)}{n-1}$,
Closeness centrality quantifies how close a node is to all other nodes in the network. It's useful for identifying well-connected nodes that can quickly disseminate information through the network. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, closeness centrality can help identify key players within financial networks that are capable of rapidly spreading information or shocks across markets.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Closeness centrality is relevant for AI research when studying efficient communication within graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

It might be discussed during interviews when talking about real-world applications of graph algorithms and understanding efficient communication within networks.
Tags: closeness centrality, network efficiency, graph theory
Closeness centrality: $C_C(v) = \frac{1}{\sum_{u \neq v} d(u, v)}$,
Ranking Algorithms and Coefficients in Network Science
Ranking Algorithms and Coefficients Click to expand
Ranking Algorithms and Coefficients in Network Science
Betweenness centrality measures the extent to which a node acts as a bridge along the shortest paths between other nodes. It's useful for identifying nodes that control information flow within a network. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Betweenness centrality can be used in quantitative finance research to analyze critical intermediaries in financial networks, such as key market makers or brokers who facilitate transactions.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It is relevant for AI research when studying how information flows through graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

During interviews, it may be discussed in relation to managing bottlenecks and controlling information flow within complex systems.
Tags: betweenness centrality, graph theory, network analysis
Betweenness centrality: $C_B(v) = \sum_{s \neq v \neq t} \frac{\sigma_{st}(v)}{\sigma_{st}}$,
Eigenvector centrality assigns relative scores to nodes based on their connections' importance. It's useful for identifying influential nodes considering not only their degree but also the importance of their neighbors. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Eigenvector centrality can be applied in quantitative finance research to assess the influence of financial institutions or assets considering interconnectedness with other important entities within the network.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It can help identify influential nodes in knowledge graphs or social networks used for AI research, considering both direct and indirect connections.

üìà Data Scientists

It might be mentioned during interviews when discussing advanced graph-based algorithms and ranking techniques applied to real-world problems like search engines or recommendation systems.
Tags: eigenvector centrality, graph theory, influence scoring
Eigenvector centrality: $C_E(v) = \frac{1}{\lambda} \sum_{t \in N} a_{vt} C_E(t)$,
Katz centrality measures the relative influence of a node within a network by considering the total number of walks between nodes, exponentially weighted by their length. It's useful for identifying influential nodes that may not be directly connected to others. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, Katz centrality can help analyze the indirect influence of financial institutions or assets through complex chains of connections within the network.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It is relevant for AI research when studying complex relationships in graphs, such as indirect influences or paths in knowledge graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

During interviews, it might be discussed when exploring advanced graph-based algorithms and ranking techniques applied to real-world problems like search engines or recommendation systems.
Tags: Katz centrality, network analysis, graph theory
Katz centrality: $C_K(v) = \sum_{t=1}^\infty \sum_{j=1}^n \alpha^t (A^t)_{vj}$,
PageRank is an algorithm that assigns importance scores to nodes in a network based on their incoming links' importance. It's widely known for its use in Google's search engine and is useful for ranking web pages based on their relevance. Click to expand

üìä Quants

PageRank can be applied in quantitative finance research to rank financial assets or institutions based on their interconnectedness and importance within the financial system.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

PageRank is highly relevant for AI research due to its extensive use in search engines and other applications where ranking items based on interconnectedness is essential.

üìà Data Scientists

It might come up during interviews while discussing real-world applications of graph algorithms and understanding how popular search engines work behind the scenes.
Tags: PageRank, graph theory, search engine ranking
PageRank: $PR(v) = (1-\alpha) + \alpha \sum_{u \in N} \frac{PR(u)}{L(u)}$,
Graph Properties and Metrics in Network Science
Graph Properties and Metrics Click to expand
Graph Properties and Metrics in Network Science
Clustering coefficient measures the proportion of a node's neighbors that are also connected to each other. It's useful for understanding the local structure of a network and identifying tightly-knit communities within it. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, clustering coefficient can help identify groups of closely interconnected financial institutions or assets that may be more vulnerable to shocks or contagion.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It is relevant for AI research when studying local structures in graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms, such as community detection.

üìà Data Scientists

During interviews, it might be discussed when exploring real-world applications of graph algorithms and understanding how communities form within complex systems.
Tags: clustering coefficient, network analysis, community detection
Clustering coefficient: $C(v) = \frac{2|E_N(v)|}{k_v(k_v-1)}$,
Global clustering coefficient measures the overall level of clustering in a network by considering all triangles formed by connected nodes. It's useful for understanding the overall tendency for nodes to cluster together in a network. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, global clustering coefficient can provide insights into the overall interconnectedness between financial institutions or assets and potential systemic risks.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It is relevant for AI research when studying global properties of graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms, such as overall connectivity patterns.

üìà Data Scientists

During interviews, it might be discussed when exploring real-world applications of graph algorithms and understanding global network properties.
Tags: global clustering coefficient, network analysis, graph theory
Global clustering coefficient: $C_G = \frac{3 \times \text{number of triangles}}{\text{number of connected triples}}$,
Transitivity is a measure of the likelihood that two nodes with a common neighbor are also connected to each other. It's useful for understanding how well-connected the nodes within a network are and can indicate the presence of densely connected communities. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, transitivity can help assess the overall interconnectedness between financial institutions or assets and potential systemic risks.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It is relevant for AI research when studying global properties of graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms, such as overall connectivity patterns.

üìà Data Scientists

During interviews, it might be discussed when exploring real-world applications of graph algorithms and understanding global network properties like community formation.
Tags: transitivity, network analysis, graph theory
Transitivity: $T = \frac{\text{number of closed triplets}}{\text{number of triplets}}$,
Average shortest path length measures the average distance between all pairs of nodes in a network. It's useful for understanding how efficiently information can be disseminated through a network and indicates how small or large the world phenomenon is present in it. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, average shortest path length can help analyze how quickly information or shocks may propagate through financial networks and affect market stability.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

It is relevant for AI research when studying efficient communication within graphs or social networks used as data structures for learning algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

During interviews, it might be discussed when exploring real-world applications of graph algorithms and understanding efficient communication within complex systems.
Tags: average shortest path length, network analysis, small-world phenomenon
Average shortest path length: $L = \frac{1}{n(n-1)} \sum_{s \neq t \in V} d(s, t)$,
Network Science: Graph properties
Graph properties Click to expand
Network Science: Graph properties
Diameter is the longest shortest path between any two nodes in a graph, useful for understanding the spread of information or influence. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Useful for analyzing financial networks or contagion effects.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Helps to analyze network topology in AI algorithms such as Graph Neural Networks.

üìà Data Scientists

Important for understanding network structure and connectivity patterns in data analysis tasks.
Diameter: $D = \max_{s,t \in V} d(s, t)$
Eccentricity measures how far a node is from the farthest node in the graph, useful for identifying central and peripheral nodes. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Relevant for studying centrality and influence of nodes in financial networks.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Can be used to study the role of nodes in AI algorithms working with graphs (e.g., GNNs).

üìà Data Scientists

Useful for characterizing node importance and position within a network during data analysis tasks.
Eccentricity: $\varepsilon(v) = \max_{t \in V} d(v, t)$
Radius represents the smallest eccentricity among all vertices, indicating how close the central nodes are to peripheral ones. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Important for measuring robustness and vulnerability of financial networks to shocks or failures.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Helpful when studying compactness of graphs used as input structures in AI algorithms like GNNs

üìà Data Scientists

'Bottleneck' questions about graphs may come up during interviews; radius can help identify such points within networks
Radius: $r = \min_{v \in V} \varepsilon(v)$
Network Science: Community structure
Community structure Click to expand
Network Science: Community structure
Modularity quantifies the strength of community structures in a network, useful for identifying groups of nodes with strong internal connections. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Can be used to detect clusters or communities in financial networks, e.g., groups of correlated assets.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Helps evaluate the quality of community detection algorithms and analyze network modularity in AI research.

üìà Data Scientists

Commonly asked topic in DS interviews related to graph analytics and community detection techniques.
Modularity: $Q = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i,j} \left[ A_{ij} - \frac{k_ik_j}{2m} \right] \delta(c_i, c_j)$
Assortativity measures the correlation between degrees of connected nodes, indicating whether high-degree nodes tend to connect with similar or dissimilar nodes. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Important for understanding the connectivity patterns and resilience of financial networks.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Useful for studying degree correlations and their impact on AI algorithms working with graphs (e.g., GNNs).

üìà Data Scientists

'Degree assortativity' questions may arise during interviews; it helps understand how nodes are connected within a network
Assortativity: $r = \frac{\sum_{ij} ij(e_{ij} - q_i q_j)}{\sigma^2_q}$
Network Science: Subgraphs
Subgraphs Click to expand
Network Science: Subgraphs
K-core refers to a subgraph where all vertices have at least k-degree, useful for identifying dense regions within graphs. Click to expand

üìä Quants

K-core decomposition can help analyze the structure of financial networks and identify core-periphery relationships.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Useful for analyzing graph density and robustness in AI algorithms working with graphs (e.g., GNNs).

üìà Data Scientists

K-core analysis can be a topic in DS interviews related to graph analytics, particularly regarding dense subgraphs
K-core: A subgraph $G'$ in which all vertices have degree $k$ or greater
Network Science: Graph measures
Graph measures Click to expand
Network Science: Graph measures
Edge density quantifies how many edges are present compared to the maximum possible number, indicating network connectivity. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Relevant for understanding the interconnectedness of financial networks and potential contagion effects.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Helps evaluate the sparsity or density of graphs used as input structures in AI algorithms like GNNs

üìà Data Scientists

'Density' questions may arise during interviews; edge density is a fundamental measure of graph connectivity
Edge density: $\rho = \frac{2m}{n(n-1)}$
Small-world coefficient compares clustering and path length between a given network and its random counterpart, useful for identifying small-world properties. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Can help study efficiency and navigability of financial networks, e.g., information diffusion or asset correlations.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important when studying small-world phenomena in AI algorithms working with graphs such as GNNs.

üìà Data Scientists

'Small-world' questions may come up during interviews; it helps understand real-world network properties
Small-world coefficient: $\sigma = \frac{C}{C_r} / \frac{L}{L_r}$
Network Science: Similarity measures
Similarity measures Click to expand
Network Science: Similarity measures
Jaccard similarity measures the overlap between two nodes' neighborhoods, useful for predicting links or community membership. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Can be used to predict potential relationships in financial networks or identify similar assets based on their connections.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

A common similarity measure used in AI research for link prediction and recommendation tasks involving graphs

üìà Data Scientists

'Similarity index' questions may arise during interviews; Jaccard is a fundamental measure of node similarity
Jaccard similarity: $J(u, v) = \frac{|N(u) \cap N(v)|}{|N(u) \cup N(v)|}$
Cosine similarity calculates the angle between two nodes' neighborhood vectors, useful for comparing node connections and predicting links. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Helps identify similar assets or entities in financial networks based on their connectivity patterns.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Widely used in AI research for link prediction, recommendation systems, and graph-based algorithms

üìà Data Scientists

'Cosine similarity' questions may come up during interviews; it's a widely-used measure of node similarity
Cosine similarity: $\cos(u, v) = \frac{|N(u) \cap N(v)|}{\sqrt{|N(u)| |N(v)|}}$
Network Science: Index-based measures
Index-based measures Click to expand
Network Science: Index-based measures
Adamic-Adar index weighs common neighbors by their degree, emphasizing rare/common features when predicting links. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Useful for identifying potential relationships within financial networks or detecting anomalies based on connectivity patterns.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Commonly used in AI research for link prediction tasks, particularly in social network analysis

üìà Data Scientists

'Adamic-Adar' questions may arise during interviews; it's a popular index-based measure of node similarity
Adamic-Adar index: $AA(u, v) = \sum_{z \in N(u) \cap N(v)} \frac{1}{\log{\deg(z)}}$
Resource allocation index quantifies the likelihood of a link between nodes based on their shared neighbors' degrees, useful for predicting links or detecting anomalies. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Can help identify potential relationships or unusual patterns in financial networks based on connectivity.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Used in AI research for link prediction tasks and analyzing graph structures

üìà Data Scientists

'Resource allocation' questions may come up during interviews; it's another index-based measure of node similarity
Resource allocation index: $RA(u, v) = \sum_{z \in N(u) \cap N(v)} \frac{1}{\deg(z)}$
Network Science: Node degree measures
Node degree measures Click to expand
Network Science: Node degree measures
Preferential attachment assumes that nodes with higher degrees are more likely to form new connections, useful for modeling network growth and predicting links. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Helps model the evolution of financial networks and predict potential relationships based on node degrees.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Widely used in AI research as an underlying mechanism for network growth and preferential attachment models

üìà Data Scientists

'Preferential attachment' questions may arise during interviews; it's a key concept in understanding network growth dynamics
Preferential attachment: $PA(u, v) = |N(u)| \cdot |N(v)|$

Network Science: Shortest Path and Connected Components
d(u,v) is the shortest path between nodes u and v. It's useful for measuring distances in networks. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Used to analyze network efficiency, connectivity, and risk spreading in financial networks.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Important for calculating path-based features in graph neural networks.

A common topic in graph theory, relevant for network analysis problems in data science interviews.
Tags: shortest path, connected components, network distance
Shortest path: $d(u, v) = \min_{\text{paths}(u,v)} \text{length}(p)$

Connected components: Subgraphs in which any two nodes are connected by a path,

Network Science: Rich-Club Coefficient
Rich-Club Coefficient Click to expand
Network Science: Rich-Club Coefficient
$\phi(k)$ measures the tendency of high-degree nodes to form tightly interconnected subgraphs. It's useful for identifying influential actors within financial networks or market segments. Click to expand

üìä Quants

$\phi(k)$ can be used to identify central players or potential risks within financial networks and assess the stability of the network structure.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Rich-club coefficient is important for analyzing social networks and knowledge graphs in AI research on complex systems modeling.

üìà Data Scientists

Rich-club coefficient is a relevant concept tested during data science interviews when discussing network analysis techniques.
Tags: rich-club coefficient, network centrality, interconnected hubs
Rich-club coefficient: $\phi(k) = \frac{2E_k}{N_k(N_k - 1)}$
Graph Properties and Parameters
Graph Properties and Parameters Click to expand
Graph Properties and Parameters
Handshaking lemma states that the sum of degrees of all vertices equals twice the number of edges. It's useful for analyzing graph connectivity. Click to expand

üìä Quants

It helps in understanding network structures, which can be relevant to asset price correlations or financial network analysis.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Graph theory has applications in AI research, especially in areas such as network analysis and optimization problems.

üìà Data Scientists

Handshaking lemma may appear in a data science interview when discussing graph-related problems or algorithms.
Tags: Handshaking
Handshaking lemma: $\sum_{v \in V} \text{deg}(v) = 2|E|$,
Euler's formula relates vertices, edges, and faces of a planar graph. It is important for studying planar graphs and their properties. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quantitative finance research, it might help analyze planar graphs representing financial networks or market structures.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Planar graphs are used in AI research for tasks like map coloring and circuit design, where Euler's formula plays a key role.

üìà Data Scientists

Might be asked during a data science interview to test knowledge on planar graphs or combinatorial problems involving them.
Tags: Euler
Euler's formula: $|V| - |E| + |F| = 2$,
The inequality states an upper bound on the number of edges in a planar graph. It helps identify non-planarity and analyze dense graphs' properties. Click to expand

üìä Quants

In quant finance research, it may be useful when working with planar representations of financial networks or market structures.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Planar graphs are important in AI research for solving problems like map coloring, circuit design, and graph drawing algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

This inequality could be asked to test knowledge on planar graphs and their properties during a data science interview.
Tags: Planar
Planar graph: $|E| \le 3|V| - 6$,

Maximum degree represents the highest vertex degree in a graph. It's useful for analyzing vertex connectivity and centrality. Click to expand

Tags: Maximum
Maximum degree: $\Delta(G) = \max_{v \in V} \text{deg}(v)$,
Graph Theory Properties and Parameters
Graph Properties and Parameters Click to expand
Graph Theory Properties and Parameters
Minimum degree of a graph G, denoted as Œ¥(G), is the smallest degree among all vertices in the graph. It helps to identify properties and constraints of the graph. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Minimum degree can be useful in quant finance for analyzing networks and finding weakly connected nodes in financial graphs.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Minimum degree can be useful for AI research when working with graph-based data structures or algorithms.

üìà Data Scientists

In a data science interview, minimum degree can be used to analyze network connectivity or find bottlenecks in a graph-based problem.
Tags: minimum degree, graph theory, smallest vertex degree
Minimum degree: $Œ¥(G) = \min_{v \in V} \text{deg}(v)$
Chromatic number œá(G) is the smallest number of colors needed to color the vertices of G such that no two adjacent vertices share the same color. The inequality relates chromatic number, vertex set size |V|, and independence number Œ±(G). Click to expand

üìä Quants

Chromatic number can be used in portfolio optimization problems where assets are represented as vertices and edges represent correlations between assets.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Chromatic number is important for AI research when working with coloring problems or constraint satisfaction problems on graphs.

üìà Data Scientists

In a data science interview, chromatic number might appear in questions related to scheduling or resource allocation problems involving graphs.
Tags: chromatic number, graph coloring, minimum colors
Chromatic number: $œá(G) ‚â• \frac{|V|}{Œ±(G)}$
Chromatic index œá'(G) is the smallest number of colors needed to color the edges of G such that no two adjacent edges share the same color. The inequality relates chromatic index and maximum vertex degree Œî(G). Click to expand

üìä Quants

Chromatic index can be used in quant finance for modeling and solving scheduling problems, such as asset trading or rebalancing.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Chromatic index is important for AI research when working with edge coloring problems or constraint satisfaction problems on graphs.

üìà Data Scientists

In a data science interview, chromatic index might appear in questions related to scheduling or resource allocation problems involving graph edge coloring.
Tags: chromatic index, edge coloring, minimum edge colors
Chromatic index: $œá'(G) ‚â• Œî(G)$
Vertex connectivity Œ∫(G) is the minimum number of vertices that must be removed to disconnect G or make it trivial. It helps to measure the robustness of a graph. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Vertex connectivity can be useful in quant finance for analyzing network resilience and vulnerability in financial systems.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Vertex connectivity is important for AI research when working with graph robustness or fault-tolerance in network-based models.

üìà Data Scientists

In a data science interview, vertex connectivity might appear in questions related to network analysis or measuring the robustness of a graph-based system.
Tags: vertex connectivity, graph robustness, minimum vertex cut
Vertex connectivity: $Œ∫(G) = \min_{S ‚äÜ V} \frac{|S|}{|V(G-S)|}$
Edge connectivity Œª(G) is the minimum number of edges that must be removed to disconnect G. It helps to measure the robustness of a graph from an edge perspective. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Edge connectivity can be useful in quant finance for analyzing network resilience and vulnerability in financial systems from an edge perspective.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Edge connectivity is important for AI research when working with graph robustness or fault-tolerance in network-based models, focusing on edge removal.

üìà Data Scientists

In a data science interview, edge connectivity might appear in questions related to network analysis or measuring the robustness of a graph-based system from an edge perspective.
Tags: edge connectivity, graph robustness, minimum edge cut
Edge connectivity: $Œª(G) = \min_{F ‚äÜ E} \frac{|F|}{|E(G-F)|}$

Girth g(G) is the length of the shortest cycle in G. It helps to identify the presence of small cycles in a graph. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Girth can be useful in quant finance for analyzing financial networks and detecting short feedback loops or market inefficiencies.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Girth is important for AI research when working with cycle detection or analyzing graph properties related to cycles.

üìà Data Scientists

In a data science interview, girth might appear in questions related to cycle detection or identifying properties of graphs with short cycles.
Tags: girth, shortest cycle, graph theory
Girth: $g(G) = \min_{C ‚äÜ G} |C|$
Clique number œâ(G) is the largest size of a complete subgraph (clique) in G. It helps to identify highly connected subgraphs within a larger graph. Click to expand

üìä Quants

Clique number can be useful in quant finance for identifying clusters of highly correlated assets within a portfolio or market segment.

ü§ñ AI Researchers

Clique number is important for AI research when working with community detection algorithms or clustering techniques on graphs.

üìà Data Scientists
